paragraphs: Born in London, Riz Ahmed, 38, studied politics, philosophy and economics at Oxford University. His films include Four Lions, Rogue One and Venom; he won an Emmy for his role in the miniseries The Night Of. He has been nominated for a best actor Oscar for his role in the film Sound Of Metal, available on Amazon Prime from 12 April. Last year he released a rap album, The Long Goodbye. He recently married the American novelist Fatima Farheen Mirza.
When were you happiest?
Preparing for Sound Of Metal. Feeling challenged and overwhelmed and lost in something is very fulfilling.
What is your greatest fear?
Something bad happening to loved ones. It’s a fear you have to accept, because you can barely control things in your own life, let alone other people’s.
What is your earliest memory?
Being in Pakistan at the age of two and having a vaccination to go there. We were visiting my dad’s family; my mum’s were all in England by then.
What was your most embarrassing moment?
I got booed off stage during a rap battle, when something I said was misinterpreted as being racist. In fact it was my response to someone who was being racist to me.
What is your most treasured possession?
My journals. I’ve been keeping diaries of filming I’ve done over the last 15 years, since I started working professionally.
Which book changed your life?
The Autobiography Of Malcolm X by Alex Haley.
What is your favourite smell?
Home-cooked nihari: it’s a curry that’s slow-cooked and the meat crumbles off the bone. The smell of it is the smell of: OK, wow, let’s eat and go into a food coma for several hours.
What is your guiltiest pleasure?
Social media: I can’t resist giving my brain that junk food.
What is your favourite word?
Tremendous. I used to play football in the park near my house, and every time one of us scored a goal, one of the kids would say, “That’s a tremendous goal!”, as if he was a commentator.
What did you want to be when you were growing up?
I wanted to perform in some way, but I didn’t think it was viable. Teachers told me I should be a barrister, because I was always arguing with them.
To whom would you most like to say sorry, and why?
Some of my teachers. I was a bit of a handful as a kid. They were just trying to do their job and I made it very difficult.
What does love feel like?
Openness, curiosity and compassion.
If you could edit your past, what would you change?
I would care less about what people think.
What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
Less admin, emails, phone calls; more space to think, read and sleep.
What keeps you awake at night?
The thought that I could be doing more: being more productive, doing more of the things that matter, and less of the things that don’t.
How would you like to be remembered?
If I am remembered at all that would be nice. I won’t be picky.
What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
How empowering it can be to let go and surrender to the flow of things, rather than controlling them.
